pullRequest.body:
A semireal ring is a non-trivial commutative ring with unit `R` in which `-1 : R` is not a sum of squares. We add this notion to Mathlib and prove that linearly ordered fields are semireal rings.

We also introduce the type of sums of squares in a type `R` endowed with an `Add R`, `Zero R` and `Mul R`  instances.

This contribution was created as part of the AIM workshop "Formalizing algebraic geometry" in June 2024.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [1ea8917c4f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14941/commits/1ea8917c4fab0ed5a6af3d137f919ca44c10cd9d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares`|380|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Semireal.Defs`|385|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ SquaresAddClosure`
`+ SquaresInSumSq`
`+ SumSqIn`
`+ instance [LinearOrderedField R] : isSemireal R`
`+ isSemireal`
`+ isSumSq`
`+ isSumSq.add`
`+ isSumSq.nonneg`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?

> Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?

Yes, that field should be called `sq_add` or something. Anyway I really think is better to define the submonoid of elements that are sum of squares. In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.

> > Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?
> 
> Yes, that field should be called `sq_add` or something. Anyway I really think is better to define the submonoid of elements that are sum of squares. In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.

OK, `sq_add` it is! At this stage I don't need the submonoid of elements that are sums of squares so I would like to first separate the stuff about semireal rings from the stuff about sums of squares (two different files, as you suggested), and then I can possibly refactor the code using submonoids when I need it.

I would really prefer to focus on semireal rings for now, and not spend too much time on sums of squares.

> > > Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?
> > 
> > 
> > Yes, that field should be called `sq_add` or something. Anyway I really think is better to define the submonoid of elements that are sum of squares. In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.
> 
> OK, `sq_add` it is! At this stage I don't need the submonoid of elements that are sums of squares so I would like to first separate the stuff about semireal rings from the stuff about sums of squares (two different files, as you suggested), and then I can possibly refactor the code using submonoids when I need it.
> 
> I would really prefer to focus on semireal rings for now, and not spend too much time on sums of squares.

Note that it is enough to write
```lean
inductive isSumSq {R : Type*} [Mul R] [Add R] [Zero R] : R → Prop
  | zero                           : isSumSq 0
  | add (x S : R) (pS : isSumSq S) : isSumSq (x * x + S)

def AddSubmonoid.isSumSq (R : Type*) [Ring R] : AddSubmonoid R where
  carrier := {r : R | _root_.isSumSq r}
  zero_mem' := isSumSq.zero
  add_mem' := sorry
```
and instead of `isSumSq r` one writes `hr : r ∈ isSumSq R` (after `open AddSubmonoid` or some other random name). `induction hr` should work as expected. I think this allows to concentrate on something else, as you automatically get a lot of results that you may need.

> > > > Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Yes, that field should be called `sq_add` or something. Anyway I really think is better to define the submonoid of elements that are sum of squares. In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.
> > 
> > 
> > OK, `sq_add` it is! At this stage I don't need the submonoid of elements that are sums of squares so I would like to first separate the stuff about semireal rings from the stuff about sums of squares (two different files, as you suggested), and then I can possibly refactor the code using submonoids when I need it.
> > I would really prefer to focus on semireal rings for now, and not spend too much time on sums of squares.
> 
> Note that it is enough to write
> 
> ```lean
> inductive isSumSq {R : Type*} [Mul R] [Add R] [Zero R] : R → Prop
>   | zero                           : isSumSq 0
>   | add (x S : R) (pS : isSumSq S) : isSumSq (x * x + S)
> 
> def AddSubmonoid.isSumSq (R : Type*) [Ring R] : AddSubmonoid R where
>   carrier := {r : R | _root_.isSumSq r}
>   zero_mem' := isSumSq.zero
>   add_mem' := sorry
> ```
> 
> and instead of `isSumSq r` one writes `hr : r ∈ isSumSq R` (after `open AddSubmonoid` or some other random name). `induction hr` should work as expected. I think this allows to concentrate on something else, as you automatically get a lot of results that you may need.

Yes, I understand :-) And the structure of submonoid will appear naturally at some point. But I really meant to take the more elementary approach. I hope that's ok for now.

I like the refactor of the predicate `isSumSq` with weaker assumptions on `R`, though, and I will incorporate it next!

> Note that it is enough to write
> 
> ```lean
> inductive isSumSq {R : Type*} [Mul R] [Add R] [Zero R] : R → Prop
>   | zero                           : isSumSq 0
>   | add (x S : R) (pS : isSumSq S) : isSumSq (x * x + S)
> 
> def AddSubmonoid.isSumSq (R : Type*) [Ring R] : AddSubmonoid R where
>   carrier := {r : R | _root_.isSumSq r}
>   zero_mem' := isSumSq.zero
>   add_mem' := sorry
> ```
> 
> and instead of `isSumSq r` one writes `hr : r ∈ isSumSq R` (after `open AddSubmonoid` or some other random name). `induction hr` should work as expected. I think this allows to concentrate on something else, as you automatically get a lot of results that you may need.

Yes. Although, in that respect, it might be even better, in a semiring `R`, to consider the submonoid generated by the squares.

I have moved the `SumsOfSquares` file into the main `Ring` folder. 

I have left a `TODO` in that file, about a possible generalisation from semirings to types `R` with `AddZeroClass R` and `AddSemigroup R` instances (for some reason, having just these two does not work, there must be a distributivity property, or some other compatibility condition between `Add R` and `Mul R` used somewhere in the file and I am not sure what is the minimal framework for this; certainly in semirings it works).

The `Semireal.Defs` file should be good for now. Of course it will be expanded later. So it is basically down to the `SumsOfSquares` file. Do you want this PR to include the fact that it carries an `AddSubmonoid` structure? I should be able to include that feature soon, but I want to make sure I understand that this is the requested change. Thanks!

:v: matematiflo can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10074915747/job/27852070520)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10074915747/job/27852071276)

Thanks!

bors d+

You have a lot of `(R : Type*) [Semiring R]`: you can probably declare it at the beginning of the section in a `variable` line. If you want to change impliciteness in only one declaration you can use `variable (R) in` just before the declaration.

It think it makes sense to create a file `isSumsq` in some other folder, and all the results that are related to being a sum of a square should go into the `isSumsq` namespace. Indeed, this seem rather a PR about being sum of a square rather then semireal (I understand it contains prerequisites of course).
Indeed it is probably better to define the subblah of element that are sum of squares, so all the API becomes automatically available. It is at least a `AddSubmonoid`.
A bunch of mostly stylistic comments, but after those it is ready to go, thanks!

Thanks!

bors d+

```suggestion
Copyright (c) 2024 Florent Schaffhauser. All rights reserved.
```
Note sure if the linter is so smart to realize you didn't use your real name.
Ok, I'll change this and remove the unnecessary import that was detected during CI checks.

```suggestion
Authors: Florent Schaffhauser
-/
import Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Defs
```
TBH I am not sure what is the problem here. At worst just copy/paste from another file and change your name (The VS Code extension can also produce it for you IIRC)
Ah, it's the dot at the end of the line
OK, I'll try again
The formatting seems correct now :+1:
You can add this to the bibtex file (you have to put the item in alphabetical order by hand I think), and cite it as [foo]
I added it to the references.bib file, but I am not sure how to make the citation work, I'll try!

```suggestion
@[mk_iff]
inductive isSumSq.{u} {R : Type u} [Semiring R] : R → Prop
```
This automatically produce the relevant `iff` lemma

```suggestion
structure isSemireal (R : Type*) [CommRing R] : Prop where
```
Should be exactly the same

```suggestion
theorem SumSq_nonneg  {R : Type _} [LinearOrderedSemiring R] [ExistsAddOfLE R] {S : R}
  (pS : isSumSq S) : 0 ≤ S := by
  induction pS with
```

```suggestion
instance {R : Type*} [LinearOrderedField R] : isSemireal R where
```

```suggestion
theorem isSumSq_sum {R : Type*} [Semiring R] {S1 S2 : R} (h1 : isSumSq S1) (h2 : isSumSq S2) :
```
Also here, `isSumSq.sum` seems a better name (still for dot notation).

Well, my impression is that dot notation does not really help here, because the function takes `h1` and `h2` as inputs, not `S1` and `S2`, and `h1.sum h2` does not really reflect that `S1 + S2` is a sum of squares. 

But if you prefer, I can make `S1` and `S2` explicit and then we'll have `S1.sum S2 h1 h2` as proof of `isSumSq(S1 + S2)`.

Ah, first of all it should be called `add`, not `sum` (`sum` is for big sums, with Sigma). If you call it `isSumSq.add` I think we can write `h1.h2` to mean the addition. Anyway we tend to follow this even if "dot notation does not fire", since it is very practical to have everything in the same namespace.

```suggestion
structure SumSqIn (R : Type*) [Semiring R] where
```

```suggestion
def add_SumSq {R : Type*} [Semiring R] : SumSqIn R → SumSqIn R → SumSqIn R :=
```
Also, we prefer having the assumptions before the `:` rather than proving the implication.

```suggestion
instance {R : Type*} [Semiring R] : Add (SumSqIn R) := ⟨add_SumSq⟩
```
I would call this `isSumSq.nonneg` to activate dot notation.

```suggestion
  the proposition `isSumSq x`-/
```
For example this is the subtype associated to the submonoid I am proposing to consider.
Yes. Although, in that respect, it might be even better to consider directly the submonoid generated by the squares.

```suggestion
    simp only [← pow_two x, sq_nonneg]
```

There should be a way to generalise `SumSq.add` from semirings to types `R` with `AddZeroClass R` and `AddSemigroup R` instances (for some reason, having just these two does not work, there must be a distributivity property, or some other compatibility condition between `Add R` and `Mul R` used somewhere in the file and I am not sure what is the minimal framework for this; certainly in semirings it works).
Let me see.

```lean
theorem isSumSq.add {R : Type*} [Mul R] [AddMonoid R] {S1 S2 : R} (h1 : isSumSq S1) (h2 : isSumSq S2) :
    isSumSq (S1 + S2) := by
  induction h1 with
  | zero             => rwa [zero_add S2]
  | sq_add a S hS ih =>
    rw [add_assoc]
    exact sq_add _ _ ih
```
`AddZeroClass` plus `AddSemigroup` is exactly `AddMonoid` (not by definition, but it seems trivially true to me)

Yes! If I use `[AddMonoid R] [Mul R]`, it works 🙏🏻 

**EDIT:** Oh, I didn't see your code above 😓 Thanks!

I am sorry, but in my opinion this definition is plainly wrong. By this I mean that what you are redefining essentially a subtype, but ignoring the library, and this is a recipe for suffering later. If you want to work only with `isSumSq` that is OK, but if you want something like `SumSqIn` (mathematically the subset of elements that are sum of squares) then `AddSubmoniid` is absolutely the way to go (or some other `...Sub` class if you want to think about minimal assumptions to have various properties, but this is not very important). I perfectly understand that you don't want to focus in this, but I think this is the way to spend *less* time with trivial properties of sum of squares.
OK, I'll change it then ☺️ But I don't think it is necessary to call it wrong. It was just a design choice.
Yeah, sorry for that. I mean that I think it will make things more complicated later. Of course it is not mathematically wrong.

Right, and you have a point, too, when you say that it is more consistent with Mathlib this way, which is of course very important since this is a PR to Mathlib 😅 

I will retake your suggestion


```lean
def AddSubmonoid.isSumSq (R : Type*) [Ring R] : AddSubmonoid R where
  carrier := {r : R | _root_.isSumSq r}
  zero_mem' := isSumSq.zero
  add_mem' := sorry
```

and start from there. Thanks for your feedback!
Using what you already have that `sorry` is done. Then you can start working on semireal field, and adding to this file only the results you need.
Please ignore the question if you don't have time: what does `_root_` mean in the definition of the `carrier`?

In general if you have two declarations `bar` and `foo.bar` and you have `open foo` then sometimes Lean is confused if you write `bar` (as it doesn't understand if you want `bar` or `foo.bar`). Writing  `_root_.bar` means "I want the declaration called exactly `bar`, ignoring what I've opened.

Here what's happening is a little subtle: since we are defining something called `AddSubmonoid.isSumSq` Lean automatically opens the namespace `AddSubmonoid` inside the definition (this can be confusing sometimes, but it is usually useful). So now `isSumSq` can be `_root_.isSumSq` or `AddSubmonoid.isSumSq` and Lean is confused (not that we do inductive definitions all the time, so we really want to use a definition inside itself). If you call the submonoid `AddSubmonoid.isSumSqIn` or whatever the `_root_.` shouldn't be needed.

Ok (though I did not fully get the very last sentence). And we absolutely do want to add the `AddSubmonoid` prefix, right? You do not want to see the following, for instance:

```lean
def SumSqIn (R : Type*) [AddMonoid R] [Mul R] : AddSubmonoid R where
  carrier   := {S : R | isSumSq S}
  zero_mem' := isSumSq.zero
  add_mem'  := isSumSq.add
```
The name is much less important, I am not against this.

```suggestion
-/
@[mk_iff]
inductive isSumSq {R : Type*} [Add R] [Zero R] [Mul R] (r : R) : Prop
```
Hmm, this particular one won't work, I think. Do you agree?
Ah sorry, you're right.
Can you declare `variable {R : Type*}` at the beginning of the file?
Can you please add the fact that `SumSqIn` is the submonoid generated by the squares? It should be very easy and I think this is all we want to know about it.
Sure, I'll do that asap and resubmit!

```suggestion
instance [LinearOrderedField R] : isSemireal R where
```
Adding `variable (R : Type*)` at the beginning of the file.
You can just have `R` explicit from the beginning (in both declarations).

OK! And then how do I make it implicit in certain declarations?

**Edit:** Never mind, got it.

```lean
variable (R : Type*)

variable {R} in
```
In the `SumsOfSquares` file, it makes more sense to me to start with `R` implicit. Is that a problem?
Variables in different files are completely independent, so you can do whatever you want. I don't understand why you want `R` implicit in the instance.
My bad, I was just testing out how to make implicit a variable that had been globally declared as explicit and I forgot to remove it. I also messed up the commit message, sorry 😖
I don't think it is really relevant mathematically, but you can replace `[CommRing]` with `[AddMonoid R] [Mul R]` or the minimal assumptions you need (just in the definition of course).
Actually, you also need `(1 : R)` and `(-1 : R)`. So I added `[One R]` and `[Neg R]` instances.

```suggestion
@[mk_iff]
class isSemireal [CommRing R] : Prop where
```
I *think* there is a subtle difference in the two spelling: in this way the projections, like `isSemireal.neg_one_not_SumSq` take `isSemireal` as in instance, and it is surely what we want.

```suggestion
  neg_one_not_SumSq := fun h ↦ (not_le (α := R)).2 neg_one_lt_zero h.nonneg
```

```suggestion
-/
@[class, mk_iff]
```

```suggestion
-/
@[mk_iff]
```

```suggestion
-/
theorem isSumSq.add [AddMonoid R] [Mul R] {S1 S2 : R} (p1 : isSumSq S1)
```

```suggestion
  | zero             => rw [zero_add]; exact p2
  | sq_add a S pS ih => rw [add_assoc]; exact isSumSq.sq_add a (S + S2) ih
```
This is the same, but in mathlib `rw` is used more or less everywhere and we like consistency.
Compared to `rewrite`, doesn't `rw` also try to close by `rfl`? Anyway, I changed it!
Ah yes, it's possible.

```suggestion
-/
def SumSqIn [AddMonoid R] [Mul R] : AddSubmonoid R where
```

```suggestion
variable (R) in
/--
```

```suggestion
variable {R : Type*} [Mul R]
```
The you can erase `[Mul R]` from all declarations. There in the last one you need to add `(R : Type*)` otherwise `R` has two multiplications and Lean is confused.

```suggestion
```
There is no need for this definition: a set is a function `R → Prop`, so `IsSquare` is already the set you want. Indeed you can see that `#check (IsSquare : Set R)` typechecks.

See my comments below for the small fixes you need.

```suggestion
-/
theorem SquaresInSumSq [AddMonoid R] {x : R} (hx : IsSquare x) : x ∈ SumSqIn R := by
```

```suggestion
  intro x px
  rcases hx with ⟨y, py⟩
  rw [py, ← AddMonoid.add_zero (y * y)]
  exact isSumSq.sq_add _ _ isSumSq.zero
```
I've golfed the proof a bit. This not very important, but keep in mind that we try to avoid "nonterminal `simp`", meaning lines with `simp` that don't finish a proof. If you need it you can *squeeze* it: you write `simp?` and Lean propose you a line with `simp only ...` that is perfectly fine.

```suggestion
open AddSubmonoid in
/--
In an additive monoid with multiplication `R`, the submonoid generated by the squares is the set of
sums of squares.
-/
theorem SquaresAddClosure [AddMonoid R] : closure IsSquare = SumSqIn R := by
```
You see that Lean is perfectly happy with `IsSquare` here. This is identical to previous spelling, but we don't introduce a new definition that then needs to be unfolded.

```suggestion
  refine le_antisymm (closure_le.2 (fun x hx ↦ SquaresInSumSq hx)) (fun x hx ↦ ?_)
  induction hx with
  | zero             => exact zero_mem _
  | sq_add a S _ ih  => exact AddSubmonoid.add_mem _ (subset_closure ⟨a, rfl⟩) ih
```
This proof is shorter, but I also think it closer to what we do mathematically: `SumSqIn` is a submnoid, so by the universal property of the closure to prove that `closure IsSquare` is included in `SumSqIn` is it enough to prove that `IsSquare` is in `SumSqIn`, and you have already proved it. The proof of the other inclusion is basically the same as yours, but we try to avoid using `induction'`, that sooner or later will disappear.
This one does not quite work for me, I think I may be missing something regarding where you want me to use this (I assume in `SquaresAddClosure`). I've removed `induction'` already.
Did you add the `Open AddSubmonoid` in the other comment?
No, but I added the prefix. I'll try again.
OK, got it!

```suggestion
/--
Let `R` be a linearly ordered semiring in which the property `a ≤ b → ∃ c, a + c = b` holds
(e.g. `R = ℕ`). If `S : R` is a sum of squares in `R`, then `0 ≤ S`. This is used in
`Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Semireal.Defs` to show that linearly ordered fields are semireal.
-/
theorem isSumSq.nonneg (R : Type*) [LinearOrderedSemiring R] [ExistsAddOfLE R] {S : R}
    (pS : isSumSq S) : 0 ≤ S := by
```
I'll make `R` implicit here, hope that's ok!

```suggestion
class isSemireal [SubNegMonoid R] [Mul R] [One R] : Prop where
```
Crazily enough we already have a typeclass for a monoid with a random negation. But we don't have the variant `WithOne` I think (anyway who cares).
Thanks for your help and assistance!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (Algebra/Ring): add `isSemireal` class for commutative rings

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares`|380|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.Semireal.Defs`|385|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ SquaresAddClosure`
`+ SquaresInSumSq`
`+ SumSqIn`
`+ instance [LinearOrderedField R] : isSemireal R`
`+ isSemireal`

<details>

```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

It think it makes sense to create a file `isSumsq` in some other folder, and all the results that are related to being a sum of a square should go into the `isSumsq` namespace. Indeed, this seem rather a PR about being sum of a square rather then semireal (I understand it contains prerequisites of course).
Indeed it is probably better to define the subblah of element that are sum of squares, so all the API becomes automatically available. It is at least a `AddSubmonoid`.
Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?

> Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?

Yes, that field should be called `sq_add` or something. Anyway I really think is better to define the submonoid of elements that are sum of squares. In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.

> > Right, the issue is that `isSumSq.add` is already taken... do you want me to rename it in the definition of the predicate `isSumSq`?
> 
> Yes, that field should be called `sq_add` or something. Anyway I really think is better to define the submonoid of elements that are sum of squares. In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.

OK, `sq_add` it is! At this stage I don't need the submonoid of elements that are sums of squares so I would like to first separate the stuff about semireal rings from the stuff about sums of squares (two different files, as you suggested), and then I can possibly refactor the code using submonoids when I need it.

I would really prefer to focus on semireal rings for now, and not spend too much time on sums of squares.

In practice it is the same you are doing, but in this way you got theorems like `isSumsq.sum` (with a big Sigma) for free, or the fact that the property is preserved by ring hom.
> 
> OK, `sq_add` it is! At this stage I don't need the submonoid of elements that are sums of squares so I would like to first separate the stuff about semireal rings from the stuff about sums of squares (two different files, as you suggested), and then I can possibly refactor the code using submonoids when I need it.
>

Note that it is enough to write
```lean
inductive isSumSq {R : Type*} [Mul R] [Add R] [Zero R] : R → Prop
  | zero                           : isSumSq 0
  | add (x S : R) (pS : isSumSq S) : isSumSq (x * x + S)

def AddSubmonoid.isSumSq (R : Type*) [Ring R] : AddSubmonoid R where
  carrier := {r : R | _root_.isSumSq r}
  zero_mem' := isSumSq.zero
  add_mem' := sorry
```
and instead of `isSumSq r` one writes `hr : r ∈ isSumSq R` (after `open AddSubmonoid` or some other random name). `induction hr` should work as expected. I think this allows to concentrate on something else, as you automatically get a lot of results that you may need.
